block.p: A debate may rage over whether leather pants will really be this fall's fashion fetish, but there is one accessory that urban hipsters should not be seen without: Modo. At least that is what Modo's developers will tell you.

A debate may rage over whether leather pants will really be this fall's fashion fetish, but there is one accessory that urban hipsters should not be seen without: Modo. At least that is what Modo's developers will tell you.

Modo is a walnut-shaped handheld device that displays bite-size chunks of information about a city's dining and entertainment options, updated daily and delivered wirelessly without a subscription fee.

The device went on sale in New York City last week at Virgin Megastores, DKNY and other stores that try attract the demographic group that Modo's developers are aiming for: people 18 to 34 years old, active, urban and in decent financial straits. The gadget, which can also be bought online at www.Modo.Net, sells for $99.
Lacking a stylus or keypad, Modo has no aspirations to become a replacement for the Palm organizer or other personal digital assistants.
''The demographic is different from the button-down professional set,'' said Geoff Pitfield, chief executive of Scout Electromedia, the San Francisco-based company that created the device.
And it does not try to replicate the services of Vindigo, Zagat's or other downloadable software services that enable people to search for nearby restaurants or movies.
''The objective is not to be like the Yellow Pages,'' Mr. Pitfield said. ''The idea is to be like your friend.''

Each day, at least four writers employed by Modo in each city send out blurbs and reviews about whatever they think is buzzworthy: eclectic dance bands or the three best restaurants in a specific neighborhood or the latest movie that everyone is talking about. You can scroll through these reviews or select a feature called Gambles, which picks an event or restaurant at random.
''If you are saying, 'What are we going to do tonight?' '' Mr. Pitfield said, ''we'll help.''

If the random entertainment selections don't move the crowd, Modo also features what it calls ''characters'': real people living somewhere in the city who publish their musings on Modo each week. ''It's got a little bit of a soap opera, 'Real World,' voyeuristic feel to it,'' he said. ''That's what we're going for.''
